Alex Lang’s blog, which has additional resources and links
Google sheet with links to successful application materials

Mentoring Opportunities for Graduate Students *Denotes personal involvement

Letters to a Pre-Scientist*: a Pen Pal program that connects STEM professional to students around the country. Applications open in July/August.
Application Statement Feedback Program: provide feedback and editing support for research/personal statements of Psych PhD applicants. Applications open in October.

Mentoring Opportunities for Graduate Students in Philadelphia *Denotes personal involvement

Rise Philadelphia - Virtual Tutoring
Big Brothers Big Sisters - One-on-one mentoring*
Psychology Graduate Students for Inclusivity (PGSI)*
Mid-Atlantic Diversity Scholars Program (MINDS) *
Building Research Independence by Developing Goals and Experiences (BRIDGE)*

Mitigating Citation Bias in Psychology & Neuroscience

Dr. Dani Bassett at the University of Pennsylvania has shared tangible ways we can mitigate citation bias in our field. This includes code to evaluate article references lists, a Google Chrome extension that predicts gender of authors, and a Citation Diversity Statement template.

title: Allison Langer
text:
Email
  
  
    
     Google Scholar
  
  
    
     LinkedIn
  
  
    
     Github
  
  
    
     CV
  

  
  
Hi, I’m Allison! I’m a PhD student in Developmental Psychology at Temple University with specializations in developmental psychopathology and quantitative research methods.

My research lies at the intersection of psychology and technology.
Specifically, I study human-computer interaction, with an emphasis on children’s perception of generative artificial intelligence (AI), the long-term effects and individual predictors of smartphone and social media use across development, and the use of motion capture technology as a scalable diagnostic tool.
My work is funded by the National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellowship. For info about applying to this fellowship, see resources.

title: Research
text: Here you can find more detail about my ongoing and previous work. Please reach out if you have any questions!

title: Research
text:
Human-Computer Interaction









In collaboration with the The Development and Experience Center at Franklin & Marshall College, we’re investigating how children learn from social robots. Check out an article about our collaboration here! We have ongoing work examining how children perceive texts and images generated by artificial intelligence that will be presented at the 2025 Digital Media and Developing Minds International Scientific Congress. Stay tuned for results!

title: Research
text:
Quantitative Methods









Using data from the Baby’s First Years Project, I used different quantitative methods to investigate stress among mothers enrolled in the study. I presented a hierarchical linear model at the Society for the Study of Human Development conference in 2023, and a subsequent structural equation model on RPubs in 2024.

title: Research
text:
Stakeholder Reserach









Developers have proposed incorporating social technologies into classrooms to provide adaptive learning tools for students. We worked with teachers in the School District of Philadelphia to understand their thoughts, fears, and impressions of using such tools in their classrooms. I presented on the results from this study at the American Education Research Association Annual Meeting in 2024. See the slides here.

title: Research
section: Technology as a Scalable Diagnositc Tool
text:
Technology as a Scalable Diagnositc Tool









This work examines how technology, such as motion tracking tools, can be used to aid in diagnosis and support for autistic individuals. Specifically, I’ve worked to design a dance video game to engage adolescents in practicing motor skills at the Center for Autism Research at the Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP), served as an avatar for the Computerized Assessment of Motor Imitation (CAMI) (study here, and news article here) at the Kennedy Krieger Institute, and contributed to work investigating how we can quantify social behaviors during child-clinician interactions with motion capture.
